posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked:
Over the course of our season, 2102 has been experiencing persistent odometry issues. We made significant improvements to our camera system and implemented 6328’s wheel characterization, but these advancements haven’t resolved the problem at San Diego during our last event. 

For the past few weeks, we’ve been investigating the source of the issue, focusing primarily on our gyro (a Pigeon 2). Initial testing revealed consistent errors of approximately 1.5 to 2 degrees, regardless of spin speed, suggesting potential inaccuracies in the gyro’s measurements. We hypothesized that the gyro might be off-center and lacked compensation in our code, so we repositioned it centrally and performed recalibration. However, subsequent tests showed similar error margins, indicating the issue wasn’t solely related to the gyro’s physical placement.

To explore further, we isolated the gyro from our system and tested it independently, sending its yaw value via SmartDashboard. This test produced comparable results to our previous trials. Despite ruling out simple manual adjustments, we continued testing by swapping gyroscopes and employing alternative setups, including a dedicated testbed. All attempts confirmed the presence of consistent, albeit unexplained, errors in the gyro’s angular measurements.

Despite thorough investigations, we remain unable to pinpoint the root cause. While preliminary tests suggest the possibility of two faulty gyroscopes, we lack definitive evidence supporting this claim. Further analysis and testing are required to resolve this technical challenge.
Is the error about 2 degrees per rotation or about 2 degrees overall?

posts.name: Dalton
posts.cooked: If the system consistently shows an error of 1.5 to 2 degrees, the algorithm needs to adjust accordingly. Detailed instructions on how to address this can be found in the User’s Guide available at [link]. Additionally, monitoring the NoMotionCount signal through the API link provided will help assess whether recalibration is necessary. If manual testing results in overly smooth motion readings, the Pigeon 2 might incorrectly interpret this as no motion. Regular calibration during robotic operation is discouraged due to its high noise levels.

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: Each time the robot rotates, the device measures an angular difference of two degrees.

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: We had similar problems with last-off-season's bot. After testing, it accumulates a lot of error when mounted on its flat side against a wall. It might be worth testing it at different angles as well.

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: We have run the test and noticed a sensitivity error of about 3 degrees per rotation. We need to figure out how to adjust the corrective error setting either in Phoenix Tuner or the API.

posts.name: Dalton
posts.cooked: Sorry for the late response. GyroTrimConfigs
